Backdrop shares much of the deep integration with CiviCRM that Drupal 7 offers. This includes the ability to create dynamic views of CiviCRM content (e.g. filterable directories of contact info), the ability to sync membership status to a Backdrop role (e.g. members only content), and the power that Webform CiviCRM provides (e.g. forms that push and pull data from your contact database). I'm wondering if CiviCRM would be the solution to my problem... I have clients whose details I need to keep track of - contact names, email addresses (for updates and/or billing), their domain name(s), email hosting packages/addresses they have, if they have web hosting with me (and is it Drupal or Backdrop), etc. I currently use Wave Invoicing for, well, invoicing, and this stores the email address for each client's billing (which may be different from their other email I use for updates, etc.). I'm thinking of moving to Stripe in the future, for better international payment support, but I'm also thinking of moving to Reckon One for bookkeeping, which also has invoicing I think, so not sure which way I'll go there... I then have my domain/email reseller account, which has my client details and what domain names/email addresses they use, and then my email client/address book with their main email address.

I really want to consolidate everything, and so I'm wondering if CiviCRM is the tool for that? I know I'll still need external products (like a reseller account, bookkeeping software, etc.), but can CiviCRM integrate with those to avoid me duplicating information all over the place? Are there others here in a similar situation, and what do you do/use?

And yes I know this could/should be a forum post, but Zulip was already open and I'm lazy :stuck_out_tongue_wink:
BTW, never used CiviCRM or any CRM before, but I've heard about them enough for me to wonder if I should be using it.
Tagging the CiviCRM guys for their input: @Herb, @Laryn, @Jack

@BWPanda (Peter) It could work. There's a good Stripe integration extension for payments. I don't know of direct integration to bookkeeping software but CiviCRM allows export/import pretty easily so data sync should be possible. The contact stuff is obviously there, and you can create custom fields and relationships very easily to track things that aren't covered in core fields.
https://docs.civicrm.org/user/en/latest/organising-your-data/overview/

You could potentially do support plans and hosting plans as "Membership types" (if you want to), e.g. allowing auto-renew hosting payments, etc.
https://docs.civicrm.org/user/en/latest/membership/defining-memberships/

There is some support for invoicing, though I'm guessing not the UI that a commercial invoicing app would provide:
https://docs.civicrm.org/user/en/latest/contributions/invoicing/
I just use Backdrop to store all that stuff.
@Joseph Flatt Do you have separate invoicing, mailing, bookkeeping, etc.?
We currently use Quickbooks for bookkeeping and invoicing, but we are trying to get off of it.
We don't get paid to work on our own stuff unfortunately.

I would have no problem creating and maintaining a custom invoicing solution, and I certainly do enough with my own bookkeeping to be able to create and maintain something there, but I don't want to create and maintain a custom accounting solution. There are too many aspects to accounting that I don't really know or understand (especially double-entry accounting), and I don't want to spend the time necessary understanding it well enough to create and maintain a custom solution there.
Oh, and I've created and maintained enough email/messaging modules, and maintained enough email servers, that that is not at all a problem.
A lot of self employed people in Canada use Freshbooks. Not sure how popular it is elsewhere
@BWPanda (Peter) good questions! Palante uses CiviCRM for everything you mentioned except our timetracking, invoicing and bookkeeping, for which we use Harvest and QuickBooks Online.
We're using Civi more and more internally lately which is awesome, moving stuff about specific clients out of Redmine (our project management system, also separate) into CiviCRM
things like what kind of support/maintenance contract the client has with us, who's PM, more info about specific contracts, etc
We're eating a lot more of our own dog food these days with our own Backdrop/Civi sites, which is _very_ good for our work for our clients, I think.

We don't bill for our hosting/support plans through Civi, that's in QBO, but we do track info _about_ the plans in Civi which is very helpful when needing to pull up quick Backdrop views of all our clients with plans and all the most pertinent info about them.
(Views integration being one of the most important benefits of using CiviCRM in Backdrop or Drupal, IMO)

yes Civi is a great tool and for anything related to managing events, people, contracts, interatcions, etc. it is the tool to use (of course with backdrop as the front-end, or well, drupal 7)

civi is UGLY, for sure. Shoreditch does a ton to start moving that in a better direction.

For me, when I build complex stuff with civi (d7/backdrop), as much as possible I build views with the relevant data for various funcitons/actions/work tasks. If possible I shield the end-user from the ugly of civi, while getting all the great out of it as a CRM.
sure there are some levels of staff/actions/etc. that can't be done via views. those folks need to use the ugly civi interface, but they get used to it pretty fast and the first time having all their data in civi makes some crazy task really simple to pull off, they start to love it even if it's clunky and old looking.

an example: an organization does recruitment events. a default setup would have them enter the event as an activity attached to the school it happened at, fill in some fields custom to that activity (how many students showed up) and then add a relationship from the activity to the people from the organization that did the recruitment event.
It's a five or so step task through different interface screens; would require a ton of training. Most of the data is entered by relatively low-skilled interns, they are good at paying attention to the data but really not at following complex workflow steps to find where to enter data.
so, instead it's a civicrm enabled webform.
All the information necessary is on one page/form.
Then they submit and a function handles all the various tasks and they end up on a page that is views that are summaries of this year's recruitment events.
Data entry folks never need to touch civi, but all the data is stored there and usable for tons of different things; and the higher level admin staff have become comfortable enough with civi to use it to look at and act on the data coming in.

Attn CiviCRM - Backdrop folks. Just released a rough/early version of a module that I think has some good potential. Looking for a simple way to allow some deeper integration between CiviCRM and Backdrop functionality. It's based off the Group-Role sync module and has been modified to sync contacts in CiviCRM groups with Backdrop nodes (of a specific content type set in the module configuration).
https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/civicrm_group_nodes

backdrop-contrib/civicrm_group_nodes
Sync contacts in a CiviCRM group to Backdrop nodes. - backdrop-contrib/civicrm_group_nodes
I'd love some outside testing and feedback.

From the README:

This will allow a variety of references between Backdrop functionality and CiviCRM contacts via this relationship. For example:
- Automatic landing pages with friendly URLs for CiviCRM Contacts (through the referenced node).
- Enabling Backdrop comments on a contact node.
- Allowing Backdrop fields (such as Term References or any other) to be associated with a CiviCRM contact.
- Using third-party modules like FiveStar to allow ratings in Backdrop which are associated with a CiviCRM Contact.

I thought Backdrop contrib was supposed to retain all commit history where possible so I left it in on purpose -- but can take it out if I wasn't understanding the policy correctly.

In the install file it creates the field itself but doesn't create an instance on a content type until a content type is selected in the configuration settings for the module.

I was experimenting with Preset for the first time as a way to simplify creating the configuration forms that read/write to CMI. I think it has good potential for doing a lot of the grunt work for those kinds of forms.
YouTube - Backdrop CMS: Lightning talk on "srcset Image" and "Preset API" modules

Generally yes we want to retain the commit history but I personally think we only do it if the module is substantially related to the original. In your case you were inspired by the original but you didn't need most of it. That's my take on it
